qas.question: Whixh population groups were excluded from most institutions of the public sphere?
Which two areas experienced criss-cross influences through noble and lower class participation?
Marmontel contrasted "the opinion of men of letters" with what?
d'Alembert contrasted the "truly enlightened public" with whom?

context: The word "public" implies the highest level of inclusivity – the public sphere by definition should be open to all. However, this sphere was only public to relative degrees. Enlightenment thinkers frequently contrasted their conception of the "public" with that of the people: Condorcet contrasted "opinion" with populace, Marmontel "the opinion of men of letters" with <a2_0>"the opinion of the multitude,"<a2_0/> and d'Alembert the "truly enlightened public" with <a3_0>"the blind and noisy multitude"<a3_0/>. Additionally, most institutions of the public sphere excluded both <a0_0>women and the lower classes<a0_0/>. Cross-class influences occurred through noble and lower class participation in areas such as the <a1_0>coffeehouses and the Masonic lodges<a1_0/>.
